content.description: Climb up thin left angling crack.  Pull small bulge and continue up into a groove.  Climb up through groove and left into big crack system.  Move about five feet left and them climb straight up over roof onto the arete.  Climb up arete to anchors.  Belay from top.  Walk off.

Start in middle of the Manzinita forest.  Head up crack, pulling over a blocky bulge to begin.  Follow crack up to ledge.  Move slightly left and climb up past two fixed pins.  Trend straight up following crack.  Pull over roof and belay from anchors above.  The two fixed pins are from some past exploring  if anyone has information on this previous work let me know.

climbs.name: So You Want Some More
climbs.fa: Eric Ruljancich, Geir Hundal, Scott Cundy  2009

content.description: Begin just down and left of the offwidth.  Climb up thin crack/seam to small bulge.  Pull on to ledge, and protect next moves using small pocket down low.  Traverse left and clip the bolt.  Pull up and over bulge using tenuous holds and move into crack/seam above.  Move out left into another crack system.  Climb up and left out of this crack system past a horizontal and to the anchors.
content.protection: Bring a ½ inch camming unit to protect move past bolt plus standard rack.

content.description: The offwidth.  Start on So You Want Some More.  After ledge trend up and right into offwidth.  Not as bad as it looks, as you only need to make a few offwith moves.  After grunting throught the offwidth pull out left and climb face up to finish.  Gear anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 5 although you probably could do it with a #4 Camalot.  Easy walk off right.

content.description: Follow the “fall line” directly below the anchors. Official start is in the slot guarded by the two sotol plants. Please treat them respectfully. Alternative start (easier): Up the slabby section to the left then back to the right after a few moves. Stay as close to the direct line as possible. Crux is the slight bulge about half-way to the anchors. Easier ground leads to the anchors. Lots of variety in both the quality and type of handholds. Lots of thin flakes that probably won’t take a lot of abuse.Lower off or, top-out and walk off to climber’s R.
content.location: Climb is on the lower wall. Possible to access the top from either the R or L side, but R side is easiest. I set up a (double) fixed line (my typical TR solo setup) using a cordelette ‘binered to the anchor bolts. Anchor isn’t visible from the ground but is easily accessed from the top. Look behind, left of, and below the large dead snag on a shelf of sorts...Start in the slot guarded by the two sotol plants. Please treat them respectfully. Alternative start (easier): Up the slabby section to the left then back to the right after a few moves.

content.description: Start directly under blocky horn.  Climb up horn, and over slightly slabby face.  Place a small cam in the slot and move up to clip the bolt.  Climb up and left on small holds until you can place gear.  Then continue up over horizontals to finish at ledge on top.  Belay from here.  Short but fun and challenging.
Fun slab to overhanging shallow crack with great locks.    Thugish moves that are easy on the hands.
content.location: Just left of "So You Want Some More"

content.description: Start to the right of Team Building Exercise at the small agave.  Climb over the agave and straight up through a few fun moves.  Pull up and put in a few pieces to protect the second.  Traverse left to the anchors of Team building exercise. Belay from top.  Walk off.  Only worth doing if you have done all the climbs here, and even then maybe not.

climbs.name: Conditions are Perfect
climbs.fa: Eric Ruljancich  Kevin Oh  Josh Burt 2009

content.description: Head up dihedral of Business Socks.  At top of corner traverse right and up to the fixed pins.  Finish on Taking out the Recycling.  Belay from top

climbs.name: Business Time
climbs.fa: Eric Ruljancich, Kevin Oh, Josh Burt,  2009

content.description:
There are three starts to this climb.  1. Start on wobbly block under nice looking crack left of tree.  Block does move, but won't go anywhere.  Place gear in seam above and work up and left over bulge.  2. You can also pull straight up over the bulge at about 10c. 3. Start on right up tree.  Climb through few blocky moves and traverse left into crack.   

  Gain ledge and follow crack to the top. One of the better climbs on the face.  If only it were longer.

Start in dihedral on far left of wall.  Once the corner ends head up and slightly left to a small ledge.  Shoot straight up here past the seam, aiming for the giant chicken head feature.   Pull over the chicken head and belay from from ledge on anchors.
content.protection: Full rack with cams ½ to 4

content.description:
A fun little traditional crag low on the mountain and mostly south facing.  Generally good quality rock, with a some really solid stuff as well.  There are enough routes here to keep one busy for a half day, and then it's just 5 minutes down hill to sun spots where you can use your rack to do Solar Flare.   

  Use the topo included in the photo area
